header_summary:
Toby Sharp introduces the Hornet Node and Hornet DSL, a new specification for Bitcoin consensus rules, utilizing modern C++ and a domain-specific language to facilitate formal verification processes and enhance the robustness of Bitcoin's consensus validations. This project, detailed at [Hornet Node and the Hornet DSL: A Minimal, Executable Specification for Bitcoin Consensus](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/d9583f04-1aec-442d-ab2f-fc10fa42252dn@googlegroups.com/T/#u#m488f43418dfabce531e1d768ea13ae11), aims to closely align with Bitcoin's protocol by incorporating full script validation in future updates, marking a significant step towards improving blockchain technology's transparency and security.

Malachi discusses the implications of potential regulatory measures on Bitcoin's OP_RETURN function, driven by concerns over its misuse and the embedding of objectionable content, which could attract regulatory scrutiny and possibly deter companies from engaging with Bitcoin. The conversation, found at [Limiting OP_RETURN at Consensus Level](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/limiting-op-return-at-consensus-level/2013), emphasizes the need for preemptive actions to protect Bitcoin against misuse and regulatory backlash, reflecting broader concerns about digital currencies' future amid tightening regulations.

ZmnSCPxj explores advanced blockchain transaction management techniques, including a pseudo-Spilman scheme with single-use-seals and a Burchert-Decker-Wattenhofer (BDW) channel factory, to enhance security and reduce trust dependencies among Lightning Service Providers. These discussions, available at [Multichannel and MultiPTLC towards a Global High Availability Consistent Partition Tolerant Database for Bitcoin Payments](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/multichannel-and-multiptlc-towards-a-global-high-availability-consistent-partition-tolerant-database-for-bitcoin-payments/1983/12) and [A Decker-Wattenhofer MultiChannel for Reduced Inter-LSP Trust](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/a-decker-wattenhofer-multichannel-for-reduced-inter-lsp-trust/1994/4), propose leveraging novel scripting capabilities and multisignature schemes to streamline transactions and improve the network's efficiency and scalability.

recent_posts.title: A Minimal, Executable Specification for Bitcoin Consensus
recent_posts.summary:
- Toby Sharp developed a new Bitcoin consensus specification using modern C++ and DSL.
- The Hornet Node aims for full Bitcoin consensus validation, currently synchronizing headers and blocks.
- This project invites collaboration and will make its code public upon readiness.

recent_posts.title: Limiting OP_RETURN at consensus level
recent_posts.summary:
- The discourse examines potential limits on Bitcoin's OP_RETURN due to misuse concerns.
- Growing EU regulatory pressures on digital currencies highlight risks of OP_RETURN exploitation.
- The author urges for preventive actions to protect Bitcoin from regulatory consequences and misuse.

recent_posts.title: MultiChannel and MultiPTLC: Towards A Global High-Availability Consistent/Partition-Tolerant Database For Bitcoin Payments
recent_posts.summary:
- The proposal explores a new blockchain transaction method using a pseudo-Spilman scheme and single-use-seals.
- It introduces a system reducing mutual trust among participants, leveraging the single-use-seal for secure transactions.
- Ultimately, it aims for a secure, efficient blockchain environment, enhancing the original Lightning Network's security standards.

recent_posts.title: A Decker-Wattenhofer MultiChannel For Reduced Inter-LSP Trust
recent_posts.summary:
- The BDW channel factory optimizes node efficiency, prioritizing strategic connectivity over maximum channel capacity.
- Ursula's channel employs a k-of-n multisig with LSPs, enhancing the network's routing flexibility and efficiency.
- This architecture enables a novel MultiChannel environment, diverging from traditional one-to-one fund mappings to improve scalability.

authors: [BIP Proposal] Mempool Validation and Relay Policies via User-Defined Scripts Aiden McClelland
active_posts.summary:
- Aiden McClelland proposed a new Bitcoin Improvement Proposal for modular mempool/relay policies.
- The BIP aims to resolve Bitcoin community's relay policy conflicts without multiple node versions.
- Despite challenges from a C++ programming hiatus, McClelland is developing a reference using QuickJS.

active_posts.title: Dust Expiry: Clean the UTXO set from spam
active_posts.summary:
- The proposed soft-fork introduces age-based expiration for dust outputs to mitigate UTXO spam.
- UTXO set size doubled since 2023 due to spam, reaching 11 GB, half attributed to spam activities.
- Expired UTXOs can be removed, cleaning the set; proposal seeks community feedback for implementation.

active_posts.title: Changes to BIP-360 - Pay to Quantum Resistant Hash (P2QRH)
active_posts.summary:
- BIP-360 advances Bitcoin's defense against quantum computing by enhancing P2QRH and Taproot integration.
- It simplifies implementation, boosts security against quantum attacks, and prepares for post-quantum signatures.
- Future plans include a separate BIP for detailed PQ signature specifications, aiming for adaptable quantum resistance.

active_posts.title: Response to Pieter Wuille's StackExchange Answer Re: Nuking the Opreturn Filter
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's fee estimation process faces challenges due to miners' unpredictable actions and block mining times.
- Efforts to standardize mempools may lead to harmful centralization and increased censorship risks.
- The call is for broader, adaptable strategies that embrace Bitcoin transaction uncertainties and variabilities.

today_in_history_posts.title: Year 2038 problem and year 2106 chain halting
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core may stop working in 2038 due to a time assertion issue.
- The entire chain could halt in 2106 when reaching median time 0xffffffff.
- The possibility of resolving these issues through a soft-fork remains uncertain.

today_in_history_posts.title: Stateless invoices with proof-of-payment
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Stateless invoices eliminate the need for storage by not keeping any state.
- Recipients face issues identifying the payer and the purpose without stored invoice details.
- Solutions include adding custom data to invoices or using a deterministic preimage for payment verification.

today_in_history_posts.title: The unsuitability of presigned transactions for vaults
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Discussions highlighted complexities in cryptocurrency vaults using presigned transactions due to usability issues.
- Large custodial operations have explored vault alternatives, with notable projects being Revault, Liana, and Bryan Bishop's prototype.
- Attempts with CTV and `OP_VAULT` seek to simplify vaults, addressing presigned transactions' challenges.
